docs.abstract: Elizabeth Gabler, the executive behind hit movies like “The Devil Wears Prada,” will run a venture financed by Sony Pictures and HarperCollins Publishers.
docs.snippet: Elizabeth Gabler, the executive behind hit movies like “The Devil Wears Prada,” will run a venture financed by Sony Pictures and HarperCollins Publishers.
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The film executive behind book-to-film blockbusters like “Life of Pi” and “The Devil Wears Prada” will rebuild her operation at Sony Pictures after being jettisoned by Walt Disney Studios.

headline.main: Sony Gives Literary Film Division, Axed by Disney, a Second Life
headline.print_headline: Sony Will Make Literary Films In New Venture

docs.abstract: The strong results indicate large companies are still investing in new technology, shrugging off concerns of a downturn or trade war.
docs.snippet: The strong results indicate large companies are still investing in new technology, shrugging off concerns of a downturn or trade war.
docs.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — If you followed Congress’s scrutiny of the technology industry this week, you would think that Amazon, Google and Facebook are the biggest tech companies around. But Microsoft is the sector’s quiet giant. It is not only the largest tech company, but it is the largest publicly traded company of any kind, with a market capitalization of more than $1 trillion.

headline.main: Microsoft Earnings: Sales Jump 12 Percent, Fueled by Cloud
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Earnings Continue to Climb Higher on the Cloud

docs.abstract: A little-known tax break allows some start-up employees who own company stock to avoid paying taxes on up to $10 million when they sell their shares.
docs.snippet: A little-known tax break allows some start-up employees who own company stock to avoid paying taxes on up to $10 million when they sell their shares.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Kay Luo joined LinkedIn in 2006, she received a grant of shares with a value of 12 cents each. The company went public in 2011 at $45 a share. By the end of the first day of trading, the price had doubled, and she began the process of selling her stock.

headline.main: How a Tax Loophole Is Helping Silicon Valley Workers Save Millions

docs.abstract: The court said unions representing federal government workers had to bring their case before a federal labor agency before turning to federal courts.
docs.snippet: The court said unions representing federal government workers had to bring their case before a federal labor agency before turning to federal courts.
docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Tuesday dealt unions a setback in their legal fight against executive orders President Trump had signed targeting federal government workers and their unions.

headline.main: Union Challenge of Trump Executive Orders Rejected by Federal Court

docs.abstract: The exiting president of the E.C.B. famously vowed to do “whatever it takes” to preserve the eurozone currency. It is unclear whether whoever follows him can be counted on to do the same.
docs.snippet: The exiting president of the E.C.B. famously vowed to do “whatever it takes” to preserve the eurozone currency. It is unclear whether whoever follows him can be counted on to do the same.
docs.lead_paragraph: SINTRA, Portugal — Officially, the central bankers, economists and journalists converging on a golf resort outside Lisbon this week will be reflecting on the grand monetary experiment known as the euro, which turned 20 this year.

headline.main: Mario Draghi Saved the Euro. Will His Successor Be Equally Committed?
headline.print_headline: He Saved the Euro.  Will His Successor Ever Escape His Long Shadow?

docs.abstract: The new tariffs on 28 categories of American goods are more symbolic than painful, covering items like almonds, apples and finished metal products.
docs.snippet: The new tariffs on 28 categories of American goods are more symbolic than painful, covering items like almonds, apples and finished metal products.
docs.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India announced late Saturday that it would raise tariffs on 28 categories of imports from the United States, the latest escalation in what has been a slow-motion trade fight between the two countries.

headline.main: India Raises Tariffs, Escalating Trade Fight With Trump

docs.abstract: The West and oil-rich areas have seen stronger gains than the industrial Midwest, which was hit hard by outsourcing and automation, a new analysis shows.
docs.snippet: The West and oil-rich areas have seen stronger gains than the industrial Midwest, which was hit hard by outsourcing and automation, a new analysis shows.
docs.lead_paragraph: In President Trump’s first two years in office, factory job growth accelerated, an achievement he has been claiming credit for ahead of the 2020 election, particularly in the industrial Midwest. His administration is “restoring American manufacturing,” Mr. Trump told workers at an Ohio factory in March.

headline.main: In the Race for Factory Jobs Under Trump, the Midwest Isn’t Winning
headline.print_headline: Growth in Factory Jobs Skips Traditional Hubs

docs.abstract: Expectations that the central bank would begin to cut interest rates this year have been fueling a stock market rally all month.
docs.snippet: Expectations that the central bank would begin to cut interest rates this year have been fueling a stock market rally all month.
docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks edged higher Wednesday, after the Federal Reserve indicated that a growing number of the central bank’s policymakers now expect to cut interest rates this year.

headline.main: Stocks Inch Closer to Record as Fed Signals Willingness to Cut Rates
headline.print_headline: Shares Inch Toward Record, Buoyed by Fed

docs.abstract: G.E., Siemens and others have prospered in a country where corruption pervades the market for medical equipment, according to a New York Times investigation. China’s 1.4 billion people pay the price.
docs.snippet: G.E., Siemens and others have prospered in a country where corruption pervades the market for medical equipment, according to a New York Times investigation. China’s 1.4 billion people pay the price.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A trip to the sauna. A golf club membership. Luxury watches. Neatly packed bricks of red Chinese bills worth $220,000.

headline.main: Bribes and Backdoor Deals Help Foreign Firms Sell to China’s Hospitals
headline.print_headline: Selling CT Scanners With Bricks of Bills in China

byline.original: By Alexandra Stevenson and Sui-Lee Wee

docs.abstract: After posts on the social network contributed to Myanmar’s genocide of Rohingya Muslims, Facebook vowed to fix the problem. Then the vitriol moved to India.
docs.snippet: After posts on the social network contributed to Myanmar’s genocide of Rohingya Muslims, Facebook vowed to fix the problem. Then the vitriol moved to India.
docs.lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — Mohammad Salim, a Rohingya Muslim refugee, thought he had left genocidal violence and Facebook vitriol behind when he fled his native country, Myanmar, in 2013.

headline.main: When Rohingya Refugees Fled to India, Hate on Facebook Followed
headline.print_headline: Refugees Discover There’s No Escape From Facebook

byline.original: By Vindu Goel and Shaikh Azizur Rahman
